pullRequest.body:
We make `ùìû K` a type rather then a `Subalgebra` to speed up instances search.

Co-authored-by: Anne Baanen <[Vierkantor](https://github.com/Vierkantor)>
Co-authored-by: Ya√´l Dillies <[YaelDillies](https://github.com/YaelDillies)>
Co-authored-by: Matthew Ballard <[mattrobball](https://github.com/mattrobball)>

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: !bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/ab3a1390-e807-4f2a-b987-0256e1beb83e) for commit 2ce7ff8b57044d677c75b99a933bb345e5125ee3.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/0336ff2f-62b6-42bb-9c67-41b0a03c868d/to/ab3a1390-e807-4f2a-b987-0256e1beb83e) against commit 90e480d89a515caeb48af97e8afad68dc5881255:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                         Metric         Change
  =======================================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.Cyclotomic.Rat                              instructions   -29.1%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic                           instructions   -33.6%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.CanonicalEmbedding.Basic        instructions   -39.0%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.CanonicalEmbedding.ConvexBody   instructions   -27.7%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.ClassNumber                     instructions   -48.1%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Discriminant                    instructions   -26.0%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.FractionalIdeal                 instructions   -61.1%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Norm                            instructions   -30.6%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Units                           instructions   -21.2%
```
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/e745842c-0151-4ed4-b8c2-15a64767a78e) for commit 19ed662704e5af9510d556576e282633d1497b7b.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/d3de7e65-52a8-4bed-84ed-2607063a86d8/to/e745842c-0151-4ed4-b8c2-15a64767a78e) against commit d96c1e7c5823d2e44c268388164cad827bd73520:
```diff

  =======================================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.Cyclotomic.Rat                              instructions   -35.4%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic                           instructions   -32.0%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.CanonicalEmbedding.Basic        instructions   -42.8%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.CanonicalEmbedding.ConvexBody   instructions   -28.9%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.ClassNumber                     instructions   -66.6%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Discriminant                    instructions   -26.1%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.FractionalIdeal                 instructions   -71.9%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Norm                            instructions   -30.6%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Units                           instructions   -30.5%
```

I thought the same at the start of the refactor, now I'm slightly in favour of adding `.val` as a cast because it really is less cumbersome notation.

On 29 April 2024 11.50.36 CEST, Riccardo Brasca ***@***.***> wrote:
>@riccardobrasca commented on this pull request.
>
>
>
>> +
>+instance : CommRing (ùìû K) :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (CommRing (integralClosure _ _))
>+instance : IsDomain (ùìû K) :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (IsDomain (integralClosure _ _))
>+instance : CharZero (ùìû K) :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (CharZero (integralClosure _ _))
>+instance : Algebra (ùìû K) K :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (Algebra (integralClosure _ _) _)
>+instance : NoZeroSMulDivisors (ùìû K) K :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (NoZeroSMulDivisors (integralClosure _ _) _)
>+instance : Nontrivial (ùìû K) :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (Nontrivial (integralClosure _ _))
>+
>+variable {K}
>+
>
>Anyway do we really want this? It seems to me that this can just be confusing, while using `algebraMap` seems a rather natural way of doing this.
>
>-- 
>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
>https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12386#discussion_r1582796741
>You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
>
>Message ID: ***@***.***>

> I thought the same at the start of the refactor, now I'm slightly in favour of adding `.val` as a cast because it really is less cumbersome notation.
> [‚Ä¶](#)
> On 29 April 2024 11.50.36 CEST, Riccardo Brasca ***@***.***> wrote: @riccardobrasca commented on this pull request. > + +instance : CommRing (ùìû K) := + inferInstanceAs (CommRing (integralClosure _ _)) +instance : IsDomain (ùìû K) := + inferInstanceAs (IsDomain (integralClosure _ _)) +instance : CharZero (ùìû K) := + inferInstanceAs (CharZero (integralClosure _ _)) +instance : Algebra (ùìû K) K := + inferInstanceAs (Algebra (integralClosure _ _) _) +instance : NoZeroSMulDivisors (ùìû K) K := + inferInstanceAs (NoZeroSMulDivisors (integralClosure _ _) _) +instance : Nontrivial (ùìû K) := + inferInstanceAs (Nontrivial (integralClosure _ _)) + +variable {K} + Anyway do we really want this? It seems to me that this can just be confusing, while using `algebraMap` seems a rather natural way of doing this. -- Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub: [#12386 (comment)](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12386#discussion_r1582796741) You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Message ID: ***@***.***>

I am not really against it. Do you mean adding it as a coercion or just the notation?

> Do you mean adding it as a coercion or just the notation?

As a coercion. I don't think that simply defining `.val` is enough to improve the situation.

> > Do you mean adding it as a coercion or just the notation?
> 
> As a coercion. I don't think that simply defining `.val` is enough to improve the situation.

OK, I am having a look.

I've added the coercion, but not all the lemmas `coe_add, coe_mul` and so on. They're almost useless... I don't know, maybe we can just add them and forget about it. Anyway I have to stop working on this for a little.

@xroblot can you check that I merged #12509 in a reasonable way? Thanks!
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/2d5a4be1-8496-4b9f-9ab4-fb32acdf3e83) for commit fb7e2a9373716c33e3cf187a347d7d2b0b0cf735.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/87394429-2db1-4497-867b-7f52e8bd9b80/to/2d5a4be1-8496-4b9f-9ab4-fb32acdf3e83) against commit 333b54aedc839303747a125277e576a12d956d81:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                         Metric         Change
  =======================================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.Cyclotomic.Rat                              instructions   -38.2%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic                           instructions   -31.4%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.CanonicalEmbedding.Basic        instructions   -43.3%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.CanonicalEmbedding.ConvexBody   instructions   -29.7%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.ClassNumber                     instructions   -67.1%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Discriminant                    instructions   -28.6%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.FractionalIdeal                 instructions   -71.9%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Norm                            instructions   -30.2%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Units.DirichletTheorem          instructions   -29.1%
```

> I've added the coercion, but not all the lemmas `coe_add, coe_mul` and so on. They're almost useless... I don't know, maybe we can just add them and forget about it. Anyway I have to stop working on this for a little.
> 
> @xroblot can you check that I merged #12509 in a reasonable way? Thanks!

LGTM. Note that with the new version, the lines: 
```
/-- Shortcut instance because Lean tends to time out before finding the general instance. -/
instance : Nonempty (torsion K) := One.instNonempty
```
on line 105 of `Units/Basic.lean` and 
```
/- TODO: Remove!. Necessary to prevent a timeout that ends at here. #10131 -/
attribute [-instance] FractionalIdeal.commSemiring
```
on line 199 on `Units/DirichletTheorem.lean` are not necessary anymore! :tada:
And everything is so much faster :smile:
maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

Thanks a lot Riccardo and all the other contributors!

bors merge

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8939597971/job/24555942153)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8940574829/job/24558970873)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8940574829/job/24558971331)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8940574829/job/24558971773)

This is a very cool PR! It is kind of annoying that Lean 4's typeclass inference search is forcing us to do this, but on the other hand I don't really see any reason why we shouldn't do it anyway. IIRC we were already having problems with O_K as a subring being slow in Lean 3.

I have been thinking about the problem of how to set up this sort of problem on and off for years now, although as a non-specialist in type theory I have not really had good answers. In the Coq odd order proof they made all finite groups equal to subgroups of a large ambient group (so, in particular, terms). But this is not possible in ring theory because given two rings there might be no large ambient ring containing both as subrings (subrings must share a 1 with the ambient ring), so we are forced to reject this approach. IsScalarTower was our solution to making all rings equal to types, and for rings of integers of number fields we tried a different hybrid approach with the fields being types and the integer rings being terms, but the evidence we now have is that this is not as good a design pattern as just making everything a type anyway. I have had generations of students finding this part of the library painful to use; thanks a lot for making these changes!
I will try to address the review comments I made in the next hours.

This is a very cool PR! It is kind of annoying that Lean 4's typeclass inference search is forcing us to do this, but on the other hand I don't really see any reason why we shouldn't do it anyway. IIRC we were already having problems with O_K as a subring being slow in Lean 3.

I have been thinking about the problem of how to set up this sort of problem on and off for years now, although as a non-specialist in type theory I have not really had good answers. In the Coq odd order proof they made all finite groups equal to subgroups of a large ambient group (so, in particular, terms). But this is not possible in ring theory because given two rings there might be no large ambient ring containing both as subrings (subrings must share a 1 with the ambient ring), so we are forced to reject this approach. IsScalarTower was our solution to making all rings equal to types, and for rings of integers of number fields we tried a different hybrid approach with the fields being types and the integer rings being terms, but the evidence we now have is that this is not as good a design pattern as just making everything a type anyway. I have had generations of students finding this part of the library painful to use; thanks a lot for making these changes!
Nothing seems much worse, and the benchmark speaks for itself, so I think we should go ahead with this. Minor comments only

Shouldn't this be a consequence of [`NoZeroSMulDivisors.CharZero.noZeroSMulDivisors_int`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Algebra/Basic.html#NoZeroSMulDivisors.CharZero.noZeroSMulDivisors_int)?
I see, here we have `CharZero K` but the `CharZero (ùìû K)` instance assumes `NumberField K`.

```suggestion
#noalign number_field.mem_ring_of_integers

namespace RingOfIntegers
```

```suggestion
is the integral closure of ‚Ñ§ in the number field.

This is defined as its own type, rather than a `Subalgebra`, for performance reasons:
looking for instances of the form `SMul (RingOfIntegers _) (RingOfIntegers _)` makes
much more effective use of the discrimination tree than instances of the form
`SMul (Subtype _) (Subtype _)`.
The drawback is we have to copy over instances manually.
-/
```
We should probably put this before `isIntegral`, then we can simplify its proof, particularly skipping 141 `have : algebraMap _ K x = x.1 := rfl`.
Can we write this as `algebraMap` instead of `x.val`?
Can we write this as `algebraMap` instead of `x.val`?
We should figure out why `simp` dislikes these lemmas.
I tried for a bit and can't figure it out. If I write `mk_add_mk _` then `simp` can use it (e.g. in `restrict_addMonoidHom`), but `mk_add_mk` is too hard.
Weird

If it works with `_` and not without it, then there are some instance implicit arguments that cannot be found (or unified correctly) with typeclass synthesis. The underscore bypasses typeclass search for all arguments (if I remember correctly).
It's not because of the `‚ü®x, hx‚ü©` syntax?

> If it works with `_` and not without it, then there are some instance implicit arguments that cannot be found (or unified correctly) with typeclass synthesis. The underscore bypasses typeclass search for all arguments (if I remember correctly).

I forgot to give more details but they seem not to even be considered according to the `set_option trace` output. So it doesn't even appear to arrive at the instance synth step. But afaict the terms match perfectly syntactically: the discrimination tree should just find the simp lemmas.
Should it be an `abbrev` to avoid all of this?
Let me try.

`abbrev` is much slower on my computer. I didn't investigate, but I think that, since the definition is now reducible, Lean knows that `ùìû K` is the coercion of a subalgebra, so it still goes through the instances we want to avoid.
Indeed, making an `abbrev` would undo the point of this change, to hide the coercion arrow behind the definition.

```suggestion

theorem ext_iff {x y : ùìû K} : x = y ‚Üî algebraMap _ K x = algebraMap _ K y :=
```
Oh! So does `RingOfIntegers` no longer demand that `K` is a number field? I guess that sounds OK to me.
It does not since quite a longtime (maybe the beginning?). But note that the notation `ùìû K` is scoped, so this is not a problem if you want that `ùìû ‚Ñö‚Çö = ‚Ñ§‚Çö`.

How about adding a coercion from O_K to K? I remember @Vierkantor once explaining to me why it was not possible to make algebraMap a coercion (something to do with head symbols, but I have forgotten the details, probably this means I didn't understand them properly). But is it possible here?

I didn't define the coercion because I thought it would require a lot more work to set up the API: that it preserves the ring operations etc. With `algebraMap` we get that for free, in exchange for a lot more writing.

The reason we can't say `instance : CoeHead (ùìû K) K := ‚ü®algebraMap _ _‚ü©` is that all the metaprogramming needs a `@[coe]` attribute on the expression to identify a coercion. Specifically on the head symbol. In this case, because `algebraMap` is a bundled function, the head symbol is different from `algebraMap` in this case. We'd need to define a synonym for this map that is not bundled and we can give that the `@[coe]` attribute.

Following what @erdOne suggests, the coercion be defined something as:
```lean
@[coe]
abbrev val (x : ùìû K) : K := algebraMap _ _ x

/-- This instance has to be `CoeHead` because we only want to apply it from `ùìû K` to `K`. -/
instance : CoeHead (ùìû K) K := ‚ü®val‚ü©
```
Although I can't say for sure if making `val` an abbrev would work, perhaps it has to be a `def`.
I know this is orthogonal to the PR but does this really need separability?

I think it holds in general, but this is not completely clear. Maybe one has to break the extension in separable and purely inseparable parts, and see what happens in the purely inseparable case. Anyway this is meant to be used for number fields...
So you want the units to coerce to K, but not the integers?
We have flt-regular as a stress test for this, where we use units *a lot*. If bumping mathlib is a lot of trouble I will be back to this.

I wonder if 
```
abbrev val (x : ùìû K) : K := algebraMap _ _ x
```
enables dot notation?

```lean
abbrev val (x : ùìû K) : K := algebraMap _ _ x

variable (x : ùìû K)

#check x.val -- val x : K
```
It seems to work.
Anyway do we really want this? It seems to me that this can just be confusing, while using `algebraMap` seems a rather natural way of doing this.
Do we need to redeclare K?
Nope! :)

```suggestion
  simp only [Set.mem_image, SetLike.mem_coe, mem_span_integralBasis K,
```
Do we need a `RingOfIntegers.coe_ne_zero_iff`?
Looks like we use the negated version five times and the positive version only once. So let's add it.

```suggestion
      rwa [‚Üê norm_embedding_eq, ‚Üê Complex.re_add_im (embedding w x), this, Complex.ofReal_zero,
        zero_mul, add_zero, Complex.norm_eq_abs, Complex.abs_ofReal] at h
```

```suggestion
    (h‚ÇÅ : x ‚â† 0) (h‚ÇÇ : ‚àÄ ‚¶Éw'‚¶Ñ, w' ‚â† w ‚Üí w' x < 1) (h‚ÇÉ : IsReal w ‚à® |(w.embedding x).re| < 1) :
```

```suggestion
    (algebraMap (ùìû K) (ùìû L) (norm K x) : L) = algebraMap K L (Algebra.norm K (x : L)) :=
```

```suggestion
  refine RingOfIntegers.ext ?_
```
unless `ext` works?
It does.

```suggestion
  ¬∑ rw [prod_sdiff <| subset_univ _, ‚Üê norm_eq_prod_automorphisms, coe_algebraMap_norm]
#align ring_of_integers.is_unit_norm_of_is_galois RingOfIntegers.isUnit_norm_of_isGalois
```
Fix this, I guess
Can this be `(y : K)`?
Yes, thanks.

```suggestion
theorem isIntegral (x : ùìû K) : IsIntegral ‚Ñ§ x := by
```

```suggestion
  map_eq_zero_iff _ coe_injective
```

```suggestion
  map_ne_zero_iff _ coe_injective
```

```suggestion
      |(w‚ÇÄ.val.embedding a).re| < 1 ‚àß |(w‚ÇÄ.val.embedding a).im| < (f w‚ÇÄ : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 := by
```
The reverse direction of this should be `norm_cast`, right?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - perf(NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic): make `RingOfIntegers` a Type.

This is a very cool PR! It is kind of annoying that Lean 4's typeclass inference search is forcing us to do this, but on the other hand I don't really see any reason why we shouldn't do it anyway. IIRC we were already having problems with O_K as a subring being slow in Lean 3.

I have been thinking about the problem of how to set up this sort of problem on and off for years now, although as a non-specialist in type theory I have not really had good answers. In the Coq odd order proof they made all finite groups equal to subgroups of a large ambient group (so, in particular, terms). But this is not possible in ring theory because given two rings there might be no large ambient ring containing both as subrings (subrings must share a 1 with the ambient ring), so we are forced to reject this approach. IsScalarTower was our solution to making all rings equal to types, and for rings of integers of number fields we tried a different hybrid approach with the fields being types and the integer rings being terms, but the evidence we now have is that this is not as good a design pattern as just making everything a type anyway. I have had generations of students finding this part of the library painful to use; thanks a lot for making these changes!

I thought the same at the start of the refactor, now I'm slightly in favour of adding `.val` as a cast because it really is less cumbersome notation.

On 29 April 2024 11.50.36 CEST, Riccardo Brasca ***@***.***> wrote:

>+instance : CharZero (ùìû K) :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (CharZero (integralClosure _ _))
>+instance : Algebra (ùìû K) K :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (Algebra (integralClosure _ _) _)
>+instance : NoZeroSMulDivisors (ùìû K) K :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (NoZeroSMulDivisors (integralClosure _ _) _)
>+instance : Nontrivial (ùìû K) :=
>+  inferInstanceAs (Nontrivial (integralClosure _ _))
>+
>+variable {K}
>+
>
>Anyway do we really want this? It seems to me that this can just be confusing, while using `algebraMap` seems a rather natural way of doing this.
>
>-- 
>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
>https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12386#discussion_r1582796741
>You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
>
>Message ID: ***@***.***>

> I thought the same at the start of the refactor, now I'm slightly in favour of adding `.val` as a cast because it really is less cumbersome notation.
> [‚Ä¶](#)
> On 29 April 2024 11.50.36 CEST, Riccardo Brasca ***@***.***> wrote: @riccardobrasca commented on this pull request. > + +instance : CommRing (ùìû K) := + inferInstanceAs (CommRing (integralClosure _ _)) +instance : IsDomain (ùìû K) := + inferInstanceAs (IsDomain (integralClosure _ _)) +instance : CharZero (ùìû K) := + inferInstanceAs (CharZero (integralClosure _ _)) +instance : Algebra (ùìû K) K := + inferInstanceAs (Algebra (integralClosure _ _) _) +instance : NoZeroSMulDivisors (ùìû K) K := + inferInstanceAs (NoZeroSMulDivisors (integralClosure _ _) _) +instance : Nontrivial (ùìû K) := + inferInstanceAs (Nontrivial (integralClosure _ _)) + +variable {K} + Anyway do we really want this? It seems to me that this can just be confusing, while using `algebraMap` seems a rather natural way of doing this. -- Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub: [#12386 (comment)](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12386#discussion_r1582796741) You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Message ID: ***@***.***>

I am not really against it. Do you mean adding it as a coercion or just the notation?

> Do you mean adding it as a coercion or just the notation?

As a coercion. I don't think that simply defining `.val` is enough to improve the situation.

> > Do you mean adding it as a coercion or just the notation?
> 
> As a coercion. I don't think that simply defining `.val` is enough to improve the situation.

OK, I am having a look.

I've added the coercion, but not all the lemmas `coe_add, coe_mul` and so on. They're almost useless... I don't know, maybe we can just add them and forget about it. Anyway I have to stop working on this for a little.

@xroblot can you check that I merged #12509 in a reasonable way? Thanks!
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/2d5a4be1-8496-4b9f-9ab4-fb32acdf3e83) for commit fb7e2a9373716c33e3cf187a347d7d2b0b0cf735.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/87394429-2db1-4497-867b-7f52e8bd9b80/to/2d5a4be1-8496-4b9f-9ab4-fb32acdf3e83) against commit 333b54aedc839303747a125277e576a12d956d81:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                         Metric         Change
  =======================================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.Cyclotomic.Rat                              instructions   -38.2%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Basic                           instructions   -31.4%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.CanonicalEmbedding.Basic        instructions   -43.3%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.CanonicalEmbedding.ConvexBody   instructions   -29.7%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.ClassNumber                     instructions   -67.1%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Discriminant                    instructions   -28.6%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.FractionalIdeal                 instructions   -71.9%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Norm                            instructions   -30.2%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Units.DirichletTheorem          instructions   -29.1%
```

> I've added the coercion, but not all the lemmas `coe_add, coe_mul` and so on. They're almost useless... I don't know, maybe we can just add them and forget about it. Anyway I have to stop working on this for a little.
> 
> @xroblot can you check that I merged #12509 in a reasonable way? Thanks!

LGTM. Note that with the new version, the lines: 
```
/-- Shortcut instance because Lean tends to time out before finding the general instance. -/
instance : Nonempty (torsion K) := One.instNonempty
```
on line 105 of `Units/Basic.lean` and 
```
/- TODO: Remove!. Necessary to prevent a timeout that ends at here. #10131 -/
attribute [-instance] FractionalIdeal.commSemiring
```
on line 199 on `Units/DirichletTheorem.lean` are not necessary anymore! :tada:
And everything is so much faster :smile:
Nothing seems much worse, and the benchmark speaks for itself, so I think we should go ahead with this. Minor comments only
